covered: Valid Payload: Multiple scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC11, TC16) verify successful creation with minimum, optional, boundary and partial inputs returning 201 and JSON body.
Headers: Required header presence/absence tested (TC01, TC03, TC04) and optional headers tested (TC02). Header type validation covered (TC08).
Invalid Payload: Malformed JSON and missing required fields are tested (TC05, TC06, TC12).
Duplicate Submission: Duplicate handling is explicitly included (TC13), capturing both creation and conflict behavior.
Error / Dependency Handling: Service/unavailable and dependency failures are tested (TC10) and timeout/network issues are addressed (TC14).
Security / Injection: XSS/SQL injection style inputs are considered (TC15).
Extra/Unexpected Input: Unsupported fields and unexpected headers are exercised (TC07, TC17) to confirm tolerant/strict behavior.
Concurrency / Performance: Concurrent creations and response time SLAs are addressed (TC18).
Integration: Post-create retrieval via Location header and GET is covered (TC20), including checking Location header presence (TC01/TC02).
Regression: Specific regression scenario (e.g., field truncation) is included (TC19).
gaps: Field-level validation: No tests assert validation of specific Account field formats and business rules from the Account schema (e.g., email format, numeric ranges, required sub-fields, enum constraints). The story references an Account schema but tests don’t enumerate schema validations.

Explicit response headers and content-type: Tests do not assert response Content-Type (application/json) or exact Location URL format beyond presence, nor do they check other response headers (e.g., request-id, correlation headers).

Exact status-code mapping for duplicates and validation: TC13 allows either 201 or 409 but does not lock expected behaviour. There’s no deterministic test that asserts the system’s chosen policy (should assert expected single behavior).
500 Internal Server Error: Server-side error behavior for unexpected failures (500) is not explicitly tested — only 503 (service unavailable) and 504 (timeout) are present.

Field length/encoding edge-cases beyond a single large-payload test: There’s a boundary test (TC11) but not systematic tests for individual field length limits, multi-byte / encoding edge cases, or truncation across many fields.
Rate limiting/throttling: While concurrency/performance is checked, there are no negative tests for rate-limiting (429) or throttling behavior.
Schema conformance: No tests validate that the response Account object strictly conforms to the schema (e.g., field types, extra fields removed) beyond general presence.
Error message content: Tests check for error responses but do not assert standardized error payload shape, codes, or human-readable messages (useful for clients).
recommendations: Add field-level validation scenarios derived from the Account schema: test email format, numeric ranges, mandatory sub-objects, enum values and invalid combinations so schema/business rules are explicitly exercised.

Assert response headers and content-type: add assertions that Content-Type is application/json, Location URL format (e.g., /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}), and any correlation/request-id headers are present when applicable.
Decide and codify duplicate handling policy: update TC13 to assert the expected behavior (either 201 or 409) and remove ambiguity so tests are deterministic.
Add server-error tests for 500 Internal Server Error and malformed back-end failures, in addition to 503/504, to ensure consistent error handling and status codes.
Expand boundary tests: include per-field max/min length tests, multi-byte/UTF-8 encoding edge-cases, and tests for field truncation across many fields to complement TC11 and TC19.
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests to confirm 429 responses and proper Retry-After header behavior under high request rates.

Validate response schema conformance: add assertions that the returned Account JSON exactly matches the expected schema (types, required fields, no unexpected persisted fields), and that extra unsupported input fields are not persisted.
Standardize error payload assertions: include checks for error response shape (error code, message, details) so clients can reliably parse failures.
